title: 110_s1199
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nanotechnology in the Schools Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings. Congress finds that nanotechnology is rapidly growing and will benefit society by improving design and manufacturing processes. It is expected to have a positive impact on security, economy, and health in the US. To maximize these benefits, the US must maintain leadership in nanotechnology despite competition from other nations. Foreign students on temporary visas earned a significant percentage of science and engineering doctorates in the US in 2003. To maintain leadership in nanotechnology, the US must invest in educating its students in secondary schools and higher education. This includes providing access to scientific tools like scanning electron microscopes and training for teachers. The purpose of this Act is to strengthen the capacity of US schools and institutions to prepare students for careers in nanotechnology through grants. The Act aims to provide grants to secondary schools and higher education institutions in the United States to equip students with the necessary tools for careers in nanotechnology. The Act aims to provide grants to schools and higher education institutions in the United States for careers in nanotechnology. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "eligible institution" as a public or charter secondary school offering advanced placement or international baccalaureate science courses, a community college, or a 4-year institution of higher education. It also defines terms like "institution of higher education" and "qualified nanotechnology equipment." The Education Act of 1965 defines "qualified nanotechnology equipment" as equipment used for teaching nanotechnology in the classroom, manufactured in the United States with at least 50% domestic materials. The Education Act of 1965 defines "qualified nanotechnology equipment" as equipment used for teaching nanotechnology in the classroom, manufactured in the United States with at least 50% domestic materials. SEC. 4. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Director of the National Science Foundation will establish a nanotechnology in schools program to provide grants to eligible institutions for teaching nanotechnology. Grants can be used for equipment, educational services, and teacher education. The National Science Foundation will provide grants to eligible institutions for teaching nanotechnology in schools. Grants can be used for equipment, educational services, and teacher education. To be eligible for a grant, institutions must submit an application to the Director with required information. Grants have limitations on the use of funds for software, educational services, and teacher education. Funds awarded to community colleges or higher education institutions can only be used in undergraduate programs. The Director will establish a procedure for accepting grant applications within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Eligible institutions will be selected based on geographic diversity, with a focus on historically Black colleges and universities and minority institutions. The Director will establish a procedure for accepting grant applications within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Eligible institutions will be selected based on geographic diversity, with a focus on historically Black colleges and universities, minority institutions, and institutions in EPSCoR states. Grants require a non-Federal contribution of \1/4\ of the grant amount, which can be waived by the Director. The Director may waive the matching requirement for institutions with low endowments. Branches or institutions receiving grants over $100,000 cannot apply for another grant under this Act for 2 years. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT AND EVALUATION. Each institution receiving a grant must submit a report on grant fund usage within a year. The Director will review these reports annually and evaluate the program every third year. A report to Congress with recommendations on the program's federal support necessity will follow the evaluation. The Director will provide recommendations on the need for Federal support for the program under this Act. Authorization of appropriations for the Director to carry out the Act includes $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2009 through 2011.
